description:
Stayed around the corner and grabbed breakfast here. Wife got an Egg/Cheese on a Sesame Bagel and I got a Sausage/Egg/Swiss on a 'Really Seedy" bagel.

Blew our socks off. 

The store is a bit uninviting in the front, but its usually the "questionable looking local places" that have the best food. And this place 1000% fits that mold. If you're not looking for "ambiance" and just want a great sandwich on the go - this is your place.
author: Matt M.

description:
Hands down the second worst bagel sandwich I've ever had. First place for worst was actually here as well, last time but I thought I'd give them one more chance. 

Jalapeño cream cheese - taste like a bunch of random herbs jammed into sub par cheese. 

The bagel - old and tasteless, all around awful. 

They charge $1.50 for lettuce and $1.50 for tomato on a breakfast sandwich making it $12 for one pile of shit. 

Cheese on the bacon egg & cheese - cold and not at all melted. 

Bacon - crisp and the only thing worth picking out of the sandwich before throwing it in the trash. 

They charge .50 to use Apple Pay. 

Coming from nyc it's a bit hard to find a good bagel shop  regardless I would caution against starting here.
author: Dylan D.

description:
This review is more like a 3.5, but rounding up due to my love of carbs and smoked fish. 

As others have mentioned this is a no frills hole in the wall, def with a layer of grime. If they wanted to clean things up a bit in terms of outdoor dining I'm sure there would be no complaints (maybe even a spike in business), however, they crush it on the weekends, so they probably see no need. 

It is most certainly is a family business (added bonus) and given the other options on Polk for fast (and relatively inexpensive) breakfast, The Bagelry is the clear winner. Yes they are slow, yes you can go get coffee at Peet's next door and still be waiting for your bagel when you return, yes they will not melt your cheese on a breakfast sandwich (noted on the register which I find hilarious). 

That being said, a good bagel shop is hard to find in the city, and if you are in Russian Hill, this will hit the spot.
author: Adele T.

description: Great local family owned store. Great selection of food service is fast and friendly with inexpensive items. Limited seating great place for a quick bite.
author: Edgar L.

description:
I came here early afternoon on a Sunday and I ordered a raisin bagel with blueberry shmear. Maybe it was the time of the day but my bagel was super dry and over toasted. And it wasn't even busy! And I don't care for their blueberry shmear cause it's a tad bit sweeter than I'd like. And I'm not sure if they make their own but they sell little small tubs of it. 
Last thought: there's about 10 seats total inside and outside for patrons to enjoy their bagels.
author: Athena L.

description:
I'm from the east coast and have had a healthy sampling of good bagels in my lifetime. That said, I always temper my expectations whenever I seek out bagels elsewhere.

We arrived at The Bagelry at 11:45am on a Sunday. It was not crowded but the inventory was sparse. We only had a choice among sesame, plain, and a few wheat raisin bagels. I guess a pro tip is to get there early if you want more bagel choices.

Despite the lack of selection, the bagels were very good! They weren't as fluffy or large as I'm used to seeing from the East Coast, but they certainly tasted great. I had a sesame bagel with lox, chives cream cheese, red onion, capers, and tomato and was quite pleased with the taste. Unfortunately though, bagels outside of the NE are a novelty, so my bagel was a bit more expensive than I'm happy with.

The coffee was also very strong, the way I like it.
author: Chelsea S.

description:
A good Bagel shop is hard to find, especially when you now live in Central Contra Costa County. I just happened to be in the neighborhood last Saturday, and here it was!

It was early afternoon and the selection was limited. However, I was just fine with a few whole wheat and raisin bagels and a cream cheese smear to go. Based on the density, these were definitely boiled bagels.  I enjoyed them over the next couple mornings back home, and decided that I need to make the trip and find the real thing more often.
author: Eric B.

description: Paid $9.75 for a lox bagel and they forgot to add the lox. Really disappointing. The bagel itself was mediocre at best.
author: Timothy N.

description: Potential.... Place could crush it but an uninviting patio, kinda grimy store, and decent bagels need work. Got the bacon egg and cheese bagel and it was pretty good, the bagel was not very fresh though. Brought my friend who got the lox bagel and they forgot to add the lox which was a bummer. Advice to ownership, clean up the store and patio a bit, make fresher bagels and this place could be the king of quick Polk street breakfast spots...also the everything bagels are called "really seedy bagels" aka RSBs, love the name.
author: Joe F.

description:
Pretty disappointing bagel. Extremely stale. Ordered with veggie cream cheese and it was not good either, chunks of vegetable, so the bagel was difficult to eat bc it was not fresh and then you have vegetable shrapnel falling everywhere, bc it's not properly mixed together. 
Not worth the wait, find another shop.
author: Sara L.

description: God awful greasy bagel. This place is terrible and their food is not edible. I will never go back. I ordered a bacon egg n cheese bagel and it came cold old and stale. It smelled bad and tasted like grease. It was as though they put an old egg bagel on a greasy pan and warmed it only on the outside because the egg was completely cold. Bacon was not real bacon either it was bits and pieces as you can see in the attached photo. This place ought to get shut down by health officials. Complete waste of my $6.75! Shame on the
author: M D.

description: This place wasn't that great. It looked really promising because it was a specialty shop for bagels... but their bagels were stale and hard. We didn't finish our food and I can't even be bothered to give this place another shot. Bleh
author: Gina B.

description:
My boyfriend came here a week ago, but wasn't willing to wait . I went back with him and waited in the infamously long line for 20-30 minutes, but the experience was certainly worth the wait!

To start, the staff are warm and welcoming. The one girl calling out the orders was super friendly and made funny remarks to everyone who got their bagel. It was fun to watch!

As for the food, it's definitely on the pricey side, with regular smear bagels coming in around $5 and a egg sandwich at $8. We really splurged and got the open-faced smoked salmon bagel with red onion, capers, and cream cheese for $13. We could've got the closed salmon for $10, but we were sharing and wanted to go big! 

The salmon was deliciously fresh and there was a reasonable amount of capers and red onion, all balancing the flavors.

We also got the parfait, with sliced banana, granola, and house preserves. There were randomly like 2 raisins in the granola, which I found strange. I don't normally like raisins so I was fine with the inconsistency. I wish there were some fresh berries, but it was a decent parfait for $5.

We also got a delicious pickle for $1 and a chai latte for $4.50. Both standard.

Overall, I'm so excited to go back because they have some chocolate bread that looks so delicious! I could also go for another open-faced smoked salmon bagel.
author: Erika S.

description:
$1 for a bagel?!? Is it 1956?

While my friends were collecting healthy groceries across the street, I wandered over to The Bagelry for some good old fashioned carb loading. While their bagel selection is pretty standard, their cream cheese flavors are on another level. Sadly, though, you don't really see them until you're almost ready to order, and you feel bad about holding up the line, so go in and get a gander at 'em before you decide on your order, because you'll most certainly be swayed their direction.

I opted for a bagel breakfast sandwich with bacon, egg, and Monterey Jack cheese on a "pretty seedy" bagel. It was plump and scrumptious and had all the gluten and dairy one could hope for in a breakfast bagel. I didn't eat the other half until a good 4-5 hours after purchasing it and it tasted just like the fresh-off-the-grill half.

I'd prob go here quite often if I lived in the area.
author: Katie B.

description:
Wow. Waited 20min for my toasted bagel w cream cheese. Took two bites. Bagel was stale and the cream cheese was bordering on spoilt. And the coffee was burnt. I've been coming here for a few years. This will be the last time.

Need to wash my mouth out. Gross.
author: Kristen P.

description:
Jeez, this place... I, honestly, don't know how they've stayed in business all these years. After a long hiatus from my last bad experience (low fat 'cream cheese' oozing out  with the consistency of Elmer's glue on a stale bagel), I decided to give them another chance. 
The place is still dirty - they can't seem to manage to ever wipe the walls down. With one person ahead of me, FOUR people couldn't multi-task, instead three stood there like dummies watching the girl endlessly cook bacon. I could've whipped up my bagel in five minutes, but instead, ten minutes later I asked the cashier (who was nice) how much longer it would take - a few more minutes... nope. I got my money back. Don't even bother with them. Pathetic.
author: Liz F.

description: Lox bagel here is amazing!! So good it's become my Sunday routine to visit. This place doesn't disappoint.
author: Kafilat Y.

description: Just alright. I came here during the week, so I didn't have to wait very long. I got an egg and sausage on a wheat bagel, and it was pretty plain and basic. Next time I guess I would splurge for the added cheese, or cream cheese, on a more fun bagel with a schmear. I think the lunch bagel sandwiches might be the way to go as well.
author: Lauren A.

description:
If you grew up in NYC and are used to a good bagel served promptly, be ready to be severely disappointed. 

I ordered a poppy seed bagel with plain cream cheese and an onion bagel with vegetable cream cheese. I didn't even ask for them to be toasted. 

Twenty-five minutes later two lumps of dense dough slathered in pseudo-schmear were inexpertly served up. I have come to expect less-than-ideal bagels in SF, but usually I do not have to wait so long. 

It was not as if they were under-staffed. There were six people behind the counter: four young men who appeared to be hustling as hard as they could and two older men whose sole contribution- between the two of them- was that one move the bagel case (that was on wheels) three inches to the right. Nice work. 

Next time, save yourself a half hour and go somewhere else.
author: Andrew H.

description:
I didn't grow up in NYC therefore I think this is a pretty good bagel. It's my favorite bagel shop in San Francisco. It's getting a 3 star because of its consistently. I think its because of a higher turn over rate??? Always seems to find different before making my bagel. Sometimes I find no spread in my bagels and sometimes its too much. I still remember when my bagels were always done right. The lines are a bit crazy. It shouldn't take so long to get your bagel. This is my neighborhood bagel shop and I would like to support it as much as I could. Wish they can be a bit more consistent. 

My favorites are **salted bagel and **whole wheat EVERYTHING is yummy. I love their sundried tomato cream cheese.
author: Sandy B.

description: Long waits on the weekends make this place unbearable at peak times, but where else in Russian Hill can you get a fresh bagel with the ingredients cooked on a griddle to order for $5?! Be warned that if you go later in the morning they tend to run out of the more popular choices.
author: Mitchell M.

description: Good no-nonesense bagel. They tasted like the ones I am used to eating in NYC so bonus for bringing up some nostalgia. Would definitely come back for more when I want to load up on carbs and saturated fat and cholesterol, looking at you nomnomnom cream cheese.
author: C L.

description:
Oh man... it's all about the bacon, egg, and cheese bagel breakfast sandwich. I think everything is cooked in bacon grease which may sound gross, but it makes it magical. This is one of my favorite things to eat for breakfast. 

The place itself is small, so better to take the sandwich to go. They have a $5 minimum for credit cards, which the sandwich barely makes.
author: Lindsay L.

description:
This is an okay bagel place. It is SO CLOSE to being like the bagels I had on the east coast, but not quite. I'm probably just going to give up on that dream. The boyfriend was also a bit sad, mainly because the place LOOKED right. It was so close.

Still, the bagels are tasty. I mean, I personally just love bread. I love bagels, even if it's just bagel-shaped bread, because they are a vehicle for cream cheese. Also, it was pretty cheap (especially for San Francisco). Definitely cheaper than the House of Bagels on Geary, and the service was just quick and simple here. Pretty much all you really need with a bagel shop. We came in at around 11, so a lot of the bagels were out. Damn it, people who can wake up early! But I still had what I wanted.

Honestly, this is the one I'd probably keep coming back to. It's not amazing, but it does what it needs to, and for a good price. Knowing this is here, I wouldn't make the drive to Geary. I'll just walk here, have my bagel, and enjoy the day.
author: Robbin A.

description: I'm from the Tri-State area where bagels are gospel.  I love this place because it is unassuming, cheap and GOOD.  No bagel compares to a NY bagel but this is the closest I come on this coast.  Bonus points for their jalapeño bagel.
author: Kristin K.

description:
Great place if you're a simple person looking for a good bagel! I got their cheese bagel with chives cream cheese and it was perfect. The bagel tasted fresh and was a great portion size. Not small but not too big. They had a great variety of bagels, as well as multiple flavors of cream cheese. And if you're not a cream cheese fan, they have hummus, jelly, and other spreads. 

They also offer breakfast bagel sandwiches which looked really good and lunch sandwiches as well. This place is ideal for a person like me who isn't starving in the morning, but needs something quick and simple to eat before the day starts.

The only thing I had to comment on was the service. I had to wait almost 10 min for my bagel which seemed odd since the place wasn't crowded at all. And I feel it shouldn't take that long to cut a bagel in half, toast it, and spread with cream cheese. I was in a bit of a hurry and thought I'd get my bagel faster than I did. But the staff was good, very friendly and kind.
author: Chisholm T.

description: Really didn't like my breakfast sandwich here. The cheese wasn't melted and the bagel was hard. Tasted more like sandwich bread. Also took quite a while for it to come out. Staff there is nice though.
author: Hayley G.

description:
Great no frills bagel place! It keeps me coming back. 

I always get the lox and cream cheese bagel with cucumber dill cream cheese. I love the different kinds of cream cheese they have here, as well as the many different types of bagels and not to mention the salmon is ALWAYS fresh. 

Super fast service, affordable bagels, and good food! I always come here when I visit San Francisco!
author: Norah C.

description:
Onion bagel with cream cheese, lox and the works totally hit the spot after a long night. Got me back on my feet and ready to face the day.

I ordered it for there and they still wrapped it and put it in a bag, so I proceeded to ignore my ready bagel for about ten minutes not thinking it was mine. Get some plates people!
author: Christine E.

description: Bagel, eggs, and sausage were cold. Service was slow and the staff were throwing things at one another behind the counter. Not clean at all! Not coming back and do not recommend.
author: Cameron T.

description: It has been a little over two years since my last review, and I will say that I should have updated it quicker. Alas, I let my yelp-ing slide and forgot to note how much more I liked this place! Maybe the first time was a fluke? Regardless, I have become a huge advocate for the RSB (really-seedy bagel) with regular cream cheese. It is always fresh, super yummy and has a nice consistent non-runny cream cheese! It seems that over the past year they have raised their prices but for $3.00, i am not complaining!
author: Katerina L.

description:
Bagels are good.

Service is spotty.  Random opening time (NOT 6.30 ever usually 7 am every day but on the weekend kind of random between 7 and 8)

Today they opened 30 minutes late and were out of lox (well, they have it but only the owner knows how to cut it?)

I miss my old local: house of bagels out in the Richmond.
author: Kevin F.

description:
Neither a great bagel or good experience: Waited in line for 30 lines on a Saturday morning. $4 for a bagel with cream cheese.  

It was not worth it.  

Bagel was the same as any other SF bagel when compared to East Coast/NY area bagels: bagel was small, not as chewy/soft as it should be, and did not have great outer texture.  Not bad (not as bad as Noah's), but not worth the wait in line.

I would have been better served going to house of bagels on Geary in the Richmond.
author: John B.
Joanna T.

description:
It used to be my Saturday ritual to go here and get my lox bagel. However... the attention of the order takers seem to be toasted - they forget to write up the order properly. Once, no problem, twice: annoying. Third Saturday in a row: I am done. In addition the lox is added in such atomically small portion, turning the Lox Bagel into a Veggie Bagel. 
Best of all, when I pointed the errors out I get attitude. Even when presented with the receipt they claim post- factual alternatives to what the Print out says. Wow...
Now off looking for a new Saturday treat.
author: To K.

description:
Mehhh... 'You call that a baaaagel?!' - said the New Yorker...

We were all disappointed in our orders. The bagels were not special in any way, and personally I'm not a bagel connoisseur - but I know when it's good.

The coffee is the only saving grace and reason that I would give them three stars and not 2 overall.

They are new so I don't normally feel the need to bag on a place while it's opening but if all you do is make bagels and coffee you should really make sure they are top notch. Wise and sons has enough experience from their other restaurant to know that they should be delivering better food.
author: David K.

description:
This was my daily stop usually every morning on my way to class or work. I always got the blueberry bagel with egg and chesse. It was a pretty tasty sandwich. They have a large variety of bagels to choose from, although I would have liked for them to feature a cinnimon n sugar bagel, because those are delicious. 

You can use your debit card on $5+ on purchases. The coffee is self serve with a tin full of individual creamers. The bagels are prepared at a rapid pace allowing you to quickly exit and get on with your life.
author: Court S.

description: Bagels are okay but the service is exceptionally slow. It took over 20 mins to toast and put cream cheese on two bagels. It'
author: Courtney O.

description:
Pretty poor service on morning of Saturday 12/5. Cashier double charged a customer, left one customers bagels below the take out area(causing them to wait for an extra 20 minuets) and then got my order wrong (I got sausage egg cheddar on an onion bagel). Whomever had cashier duty needs to be retrained and talked to. I've been going here since I moved to RH 4 years ago, and they was by FAR the worst it's been. On top of that, bagel came out cold and with wrong ingredients. 

Figure it out or continue to lose customers.
author: Jared G.

description:
My 5-star reviews are pretty rare for "new" places... but this gem on Russian Hill was awesome.

I had to move my car by 9am cause I couldn't find parking at night and the hotel mgr said I could block one of the 2 driveways if I moved it by 9. There was still no parking their so I decided to try out Star Bagels...

However... driving down Van Ness, we realized their was a Starbucks next to Bagelry so we drove the extra 1/2 mile there.

I got the "Really Seedy" bagel... cause it was highly spoken of here on Yelp and it didn't disappoint. It was awesome. I added Lox spread cream which was good... I added Lox and theirs was perfect. I've had Lox at 4 different spots now (NY Bagel Bistro, Noah's and Western Bagel) and this one moved to the top of the awesome list. Wasn't too salty. Perfect balance of taste. The texture was immaculate and nicely sliced big succulent chunks of smoked salmon. 

AND THEY HAD CAPERS!!! I love capers and so far Noah's is the only bagel place that's had it. Props San Francisco. Normally it comes with Onions, Tomatoes, Lettuce and Cucumbers but I forgoed all that nonsensical nonsense.

But yeah "Really Seedy bagel + Lox + Capers + Salmon Cream Cheese = 5-stars."

Normal bagels were $2.50... my creation was $6.50 and came with a choice of soda or bottled water. Good job Bagelry!!!
author: Shaun W.

description:
This place is an easy location for me to grab a quick bite before work or during my lunch break. I've been in a few times but I didn't see a menu board to order. It wasn't until I looked around and saw a laminated piece of paper on the wall and counter where you could order from different flavored spreads, breakfast and lunch bagels. 

I ordered a plain bagel w/ fried egg, ham and choice of cheese (provolone). My order was ready in less than 5 mins. The offer self serve coffee (there's a charge for refills). It's a small place, seating inside and outside, and many choices of bagels to choose from (plain, everything, cheese, cheddar jalapeño, etc). It's bigger than a regular sized bagel, enough for breakfast and lunch! 

Will definitely be back to try other bagel sandwiches they have!
author: Maellene D.

description:
My favorite bagel shop of all time. Never change Bagelry, and please never, ever leave. 

I have been going to the Bagelry since I was a toddler, and lived across the street from it's current location-- still the best ever, and I now live in NYC. Better than ANY I've ever had here, for sure....as soon as I fly home I go to the Bagelry. ;)
author: Anna H.

description:
Tasty inexpensive bagles.  Fast happy service.
if they had better coffee i would rate them 5 stars
author: Garth E.

description:
Other than this one weird experience this place is fantastic. Delicious bagels. Affordable prices. Lots of a great add-on options.

But this one time I paid with a $20 and got change as if I'd paid with a $10. I spent 20min fighting with the staff before they reluctantly gave me the $10 and said I wouldn't be welcome back. It was the strangest experience I've ever had a a bagel spot like this. I asked them to check the cameras and they said it didn't show up. I still come back whenever I feel like it.
author: Ryan G.

description: Bagels can be hard to get right, but each time I've been to The Bagelry, I've had a reasonably good experience.  Things move fast, they have a number of options from both a bagel and cream cheese perspective, and it's priced reasonably.  I enjoy that it's a small and independent shop, and not a chain too.  On the weekends, this place can get really busy and it could potentially take a long time to get your food, but I've found that having a good bagel is worth the wait, so wait I shall.
author: Lisa I.

description:
This review is based on the customer service and execution:
-staff frequently forgets to include toppings such as avocado.  Need to personally check the order every time to see if/what they forgot.  Avg 1 in every 5 orders they will make a mistake. This happens regardless of how busy they are.
-depending on the cashier, price of the order varies by $0.50-$1.50 because they are not consistent about how they enter it into the pos system. Also it seems price of toppings such as bacon or avocado change but not all the staff is aware or mind ful.  Also need to check this every time... Very frustrating!

Quality of food is 3.5 stars, except avocados which can sometimes be pretty old/brown.

This place could be so much better if they got their act together.
author: Leland F.

description: I work right across the street from this place and it's always very convenient for me to grab a bagel in the morning here. First time I came here the guy taking orders confused everything and gave me one extra plain bagel which i didn't need. It was fine, I never said anything. The second time I went here, when I ordered poppyseed bagel w/ dried tomatoes, cream cheese and avocado ON THE SIDE. In addition to the fact that I waited for about 20 minutes for my bagel to be ready - which is ridiculous, there was no sausage in it or anything that needed some extra time to prepare, just cream cheese and sliced avocado,- when I opened it I saw avocado, cream cheese and FRESH tomatoes inside the bagel. Will never go back.
author: Alina S.

description:
Friendly & speedy service. Good variety of fresh bagels.

I love their warm bagels. The BTL was delish. All their sandwich style bagels seem like a bargain as they all fall in the $3-4 range- great for a really hearty breakfast or a filing lunch on a low budget.

Their LOX with cream cheese at $6.75 though was just ok - salmon was rather mushy..made me wonder where they sourced it from. 

They do have some stools inside and a few outside tables if you choose to sit here. Overall, a convenient addition to the Polk neighborhood!
author: Veronica S.

description: I live a block away and have gone to the Bagelry at least 3 times a week for the past 15 years. Great bagels, nice people run the place. Saturdays and Sundays get a bit packed and there is a line but whatever it's not McDonalds with a drive-through. You can call-in and order over the phone and avoid the lines...duh. The everything bagel toasted with 'easy' on the cream cheese and cucumber and bacon is insanely good. Go there you will be happy...unless you are from the east coast and are constantly raving about how good the bagels and pizza are there. There is a reason why you live here now...the weather in Boston and the rest of the east coast blows, bottom line.
author: Dan F.

description:
Whenever I'm not in Saratoga, I always miss my beloved Saratoga Bagels. However, the Bagelry offers an acceptable substitution for when I'm in the city.

Took a me a few tries... but I finally figured out the perfect morning bagel sandwich:

Salt bagel
Swiss Cheese
Egg
Avocado

I learned that with a regular bagel, the sandwich lacks salt. With a salt bagel and ham, the bagel is too salty. With cheddar cheese, the bagel sandwich is too greasy. Without cheese, the sandwich is too dry. (You can tell it took a few times...)

Anyways, with my perfect bagel sandwich combination, you get the salty bagel (salted evenly top AND bottom), the creamy cheese, the savory egg, and the light avocado all in the same delightful meal.

The wait usually isn't more than 5 min... but it has taken me up to 20 minutes on really busy days.

Their lunch sandwiches are good too!
author: Michelle L.

description: Great bagels. Slowest service on the planet. 20 min for two toasted bagels with schmear; meanwhile the family is behind the counter talking and having fun. Not good to see for customers waiting a long time to be served.
author: ryan a.

description: Great bagel sandwiches for us Monday through Friday commuters! I get egg and cheese on a bagel and they make it quickly and I'm out the door! Great selection too!! They're very nice and willing to help without you thinking you're being a pain in the butt. Love it!!
author: Sandra P.

description: The only place with house made bagels I have found in the area, and the breakfast sandwiches cost about the same as every other cafe serving them on Costco Kirkland brand bagels. Just wish they would have more variety. When I went in there on a Sunday around noon they only had about four types available.
author: Shabnam E.

description: This is the best bagel in SF so I'm rating it by those standards. If you're from the east coast, you might be disappointed-for some reason, good bagels are really hard to find here. The bagels are very reasonable and fresh but they do run out of things pretty quickly. This is our go to spot to pick up bagels for breakfast-really seedy bagels, salt bagels, egg bagels are all very good. Their lox sandwich is good as well and maybe the cheapest lox sandwich I've seen in a while.
author: Amber F.

description:
Going to The Bagelry is like experiencing a robbery.  Your expectations will be destroyed and taken away.   Staff was very rude, bagel was so-so at best.  Grungy decor, felt dirty eating there.  Have no idea how this place gets good reviews.

The coffee here is, literally, sewage water.  So awful.  Like why not bother with good coffee?  Makes no sense.  Avoid this place at all cost.
author: Monte R.

description: Used to like this place but I found mold in my turkey sandwich today. Disgusting.
author: Tina R.

description: A great no frills bagel spot. I got the lox and cream cheese on an everything bagel and it was great. And for $7 on polk st? Thats awesome. Just when you thought sf was ruined by shitheads theres a dope bagel spot that has affordable delicious bagels.
author: Troy R.

description:
We grabbed a bagel for breakfast on our trip. I got the jalapeno bagel with plain cream cheese for $2.50.They have breakfast sandwiches, too ranging from $3.50 to around $5. 

Casual, small spot to eat your bagel and enjoy some drip coffee. Not much seating  but there are some tables outside. Cash only. 

Good bagel, I'd return!
author: Chelsea J.

description:
Just go to Starbucks for a bagel. Have come in here many times and always questioned the freshness of their bagels. Yesterday's visit gave me the answer that I was looking for.

Came in as soon as they opened at 6:40 am and asked for the jalapeno cheese bagel. They didn't have it. Onion bagel? "We're out of those already." 

How can you be out when you just opened? Soo, they are selling yesterday's bagels while they bake a new batch? Or just selling day old bagels to get rid of them. Either way, they should not be posing those bagels as fresh when they're clearly not. A bagel house should have all varieties in dozens, ready to go as soon as they open! They shouldn't have just five random choices of all the terrible ones (salt, sesame!) 

Not fresh.
author: Joy A.

description:
The Bagelry makes your standard bagel types (wheat, plain, egg, poppy, onion, garlic, etc.) for $1 each. It also offers plenty of cream cheese spreads, bagel egg sandwiches, croissants and pretzels. 

The bagels are about the same size as Noah's and they toast up nicely (light, crispy shell, soft interior). They're fairly firm but I like my bagels to be a little firmer and chewier.

* Herb cream cheese: had a lot going on, not sure if I liked it, possibly too many herbs

Frequent bagel buyer stamp card available.

Cash only.
author: Lolia S.

description: Best bagels I have had in San Francisco. Their egg bagel sandwich is legit. Even cook the eggs right in front of you and you can generally get in and out really fast...
author: Gary G.

description: These are the closest to an east coast bagel to be found in San Francisco. But you should be ready to wait, they take forever to get orders through. Something is wrong in their process, I've waited over 40 minutes before for two bagels with cream cheese.
author: Kate S.

description: I've been a Bagelry customer for well over 10 years and since it was purchased by the present owner which I thought was an improvement over the previous.  Obviously not part of any chain (support your local small businesses!) and the "help" is very helpful.  And cute. They make whatever you want, "your way," and I usually go with toasted "really seedy" bagel with lox spread, red onion, and tomato on the side which I wisk home and add capers and a pinch of Hawaiian rock salt and toast the toast with my cup of home java ...
author: Terry A.

description: I was 100% pleased with my experience.  There was no wait when I came in at 9 a.m. on a Tuesday morning and the person at the counter was very helpful and engaging.  I am a native San Franciscan so admittedly have little right to comment on NYC bagel authenticity.  I will say my favorite bagel when visiting NYC is Murray's and I found these bagels to be different than Murray's but also excellent--good crust and good chewiness.  My favorite part is that as a vegan I sometimes run into problems getting vegan spreads.  I was absolutely delighted with the West Coast Vegetarian sandwich--truly unique and very, very delicious--Shwarma squash, pickled red onions and hummus.  Hmmm!  Totally yummy!  My next visit I will probably order the smashed avocado or perhaps the almond butter.  I love that vegans have choices.
author: Patti M.

description:
To enter The Bagelry is to enter a twisted version of the slow food movement. Curt employees take mere milliseconds to record your order, no matter how complicated, and then proceed to take their sweet time schmearing a thin layer of creme cheese.

Bagel with cream cheese? Five minutes waiting in front of their counter. Bagel with a slice of tomato and cream cheese? Ten minutes. You want an egg on that? Maybe it will be ready by Christmas.

The real kicker is that they don't even have good bagels. Being an east coaster, I get that it takes competition between the likes of Tal, Essabagel, and Zabars to raise the average to firm, savory heaven. But The Bagelry is the equivalent of a bag of frozen pucks you pick up when Stop 'n Shop puts them on clearance. Those heirloom tomatoes that grace many nearby restaurants are nowhere to be found here, where bland mealy things are used.
author: Trevor S.

description: Ordered a bacon egg bagel and they left off the bacon and egg. Weak on the veggies too. Never coming here again
author: Ryan B.

description:
The Bagelry agrees to issue a Scoutmob Coupon in November that doesn't expire until 5/17/2012. NOW (as of Feb 2012) THEY REFUSE TO HONOR IT.

Jeez, talk about a "bait and switch".  This is sad b/c they have great bagels, but  now they have such poor business practices I can never go back.

BOOOOl - That is a dirtbag move, if you couldn't handle the traffic then you should have put a limit on Scoutmobs issued/offered  - OR made the expire date closer in.
author: Amy W.

description:
Since moving to sf I've been on the lookout for a good bagel place. This place was decent, but nothing to blow me away. The prices are pretty good, and I'd come back - but I'd still like to find a better bagel place in sf.

I got the veggie sandwich on an everything bagel. They were out of the onion bagel, which was also a little frustrating.
author: Amaresh S.

description: Best Salmon Bagel in Russian Hill for the price, possibly SF. Always a consistently great taste, large portion and complete meal with plenty of cream cheese, sprouts, cucumber, and capers. Visit at least once a week, and never disappoints. Fast, unassuming service too. Keep up the good work.
author: Karl V.

description:
So, here's the sitch - This place is amazing for bagel SANDWICHES. Ie: Egg, cheese, bagel, bacon, etc. Why? Because they individually fry each egg. None of this poached egg in the microwave stuff that so often happens in small breakfast places. 

For normal bagels and cream cheese? I prefer Noah's. Nothing super special about the Bagelry's cream cheese.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Rye Bagel (when they have it...each day they have different special bagels), fried egg, sausage (yey non-pre-processed breakfast sandwich meat!), pesto sun dried tomato cream cheese...best bagel sandwich eva.

They also have more cream cheesys:  dill and cucumber, garlic, veggie, strawberry, walnut, plain...and more

The blueberry bagel, sausage, egg and walnut cream cheese combo tasted like a hearty pancake...unexpected, but delicious!

The setup is really nice too. Right next to coffee shops, a nice little area to sit outside. Lovely.
author: Ra N.

description:
Best bagels in SF. Having lived in NYC, I have been spoiled by high quality bagels. While Bagelry isn't NY-level, they come pretty damn close for being 3,000 miles away.

The bagel & lox is delicious-- but ask for no tomatoes-- they are rarely fresh. 

Perfect neighborhood spot when you're looking for a quick meal on a Saturday or Sunday morning.
author: Geoff R.

description:
Just say no. The service was SO incredibly slow. Like, SO slow. There were about 5 people working and like, 8 customers, so I'm not sure what took them so long to toast and schmear my bagel but apparently it took close to 20 minutes. 

The bagel was not even remotely worth it (tasted like a safeway brand bagel) and they skimped on the cream cheese. The employees are high school kids who have no idea how to deal with angry, hungry customers. 

Avoid avoid avoid.
author: Carmen K.

description: I've come here several times on the weekend and each time I leave slightly disappointed. I feel like their prices are quite high for the size of the bagel you get. Also, each time I come here it seems like it takes forever to get your food. I have only ordered toasted bagels with cream cheese. The last time I came I got my bagel un-toasted and cream cheese on the side and took it home to do myself. This worked out much better and was very fast. I come here mostly out of convenience, but if it wasn't a few blocks away I don't think I would come. I have had better much better bagels than what The Bagelry has to offer. On the weekend though when I'm hungover and craving a bagel, this place gets the job done.
author: Lacey L.

description: Closest thing to a real (NY) bagel in the bay area. It's not a fluffy little bread circle (Noah's) it actually has substance, and they make rye.
author: jim K.

description: This place seems to be getting slower each time I go here. They should invest in more staff on the weekend to speed up their process.
author: Scoot S.

description: I'll give this place the benefit of the doubt since they are usually amazing, but I am disappointed lately since the general quality has gone down and they cannot seem to take my order correctly. Egg ham and cheese does not mean ham and cheese and charge me for the egg. I understand you are super busy but this has happened twice in a row!
author: Aaron K.

description:
The bagels are a-ok and reasonably priced, but the service leaves something to be desired.

Every time I go there it doesn't seem particularly busy, but it takes a rather long time for anyone to acknowledge me. I've seen people leave and come back after 5-10 minutes because it's just a lot of standing around for no apparent reason.

The last time I went there I stood in front of the register and waited to order. It became very clear that everyone behind the counter assumed I had been helped, since they actually discussed it right in front of me. Nope...just waiting politely, folks. Can't really make it much more obvious...I tend to move away from the register after I'm done ordering at food joints....

I wouldn't normally think this was necessary for a bagel place, but perhaps calling in your order is the way to go....?
author: Katie S.

description: They have jalapeno cream cheese, enough said.
author: Nicole Z.

description: Oops! I meant to review another place, and cannot delete entry, so please discount this review, I will give benefit of the doubt here and rate above avg.
author: Eddie C.

description: Even if you like them, $2 for an undersized bagel is enough to cost The Bagelry a star. Wise Bros is a big step up from Noah's and Posh's puffy rolls with a hole, which they erroneously call bagels. If your standard for a bagel is NYC (including Brooklyn), then you will be disappointed by The Bagelry; I don't think that they would survive more than a few months on the Upper West Side or in Park Slope against the local competition there.  But if you have grown up with the unboiled things available at Safeway and Noah's, then The Bagelry is a noticeable improvement, though hardly a good value.
author: Tony W.

description: Seriously legitimate bagels. Perhaps the best in San Francisco. If you stop there for lunch, no line (at least during the weekdays). Will be back!
author: Mel G.

description:
Best bagel in the city.  My secret for choosing from bagels is this: real bagels do not have holes--they are so fat that the holes are all filled in!  Any bagel that is less than fat doesn't have enough yeast, and so hasn't risen high enough, and will therefore have a shitty texture (note: this theory is completely unscientific and yet somehow always true).  

The Bagelry is the ONLY bagel shop I have found in the City of SF that passes this test.  (Not House of Bagels--gross!  spongy!  why do all the cafes seem to use them?!  Not Katz's--too dense!  ick!)  DO NOT SETTLE FOR A SKINNY BAGEL!  Just say no.  Then go to the Bagelry.
author: Joanna L.

description:
The bagels are ok but the service is so incredibly slow. It takes more than 20 minutes for the 5 people who work there to make a sandwich where there are no more than 10 people in line. I have experienced such slow service every time I go there. If you are trying to catch a bus or something, don't stop there, it will ruin your trip. 

To be fair, the problem though is not the employees based on my observation. Folks work hard in the store. The materials and tools are disorganized, so people run into each other all the time trying to reach what they need. That's causing the backlog of orders in the queue. People looked busy but productivity is low. 

It seems like there is a massive space in the back full of stuff that has nothing to do with making bagels making the place look disorganized. This place need to clean up the waiting area for a better customer experience.
author: Desmond L.

description: Fresh  bagels and smack in the middle of a Starbucks and Peet's Coffee. How can you go wrong? Tons of cream cheese options as well. Can't complain. It is just one of those places to pick up and go though, dont bother sticking around as it is not really the most inviting place on earth.
author: Derek S.

description:
At a base of $1 a bagel (or flat everything thing) with lowering price as volume goes up you can stock up on some bagels or their house made whipped spreads, including chives and strawberry flavors amoung others.  Or opting for their sandwiches is a swell idea if you're looking to just get a little meal in.  

The one qualm I have with this place is the same as many other budget breakfast places in this city. Often I can't get a good cup of hot coffee to sit their with.  Oh well maybe one day I'll find a breakfast spot I don't want to carry a coffee into
author: Matthew M.

description: Definitely don't order the blueberry cream cheese. It's food coloring mixed with a watery mixture of what can be hardly be described as cream cheese.
author: Drew D.

description: We got here at 8:30 Saturday morning (free parking til 9!) and the line was already to the door. I got a lox and cream cheese garlic bagel (comes with tomato, onions, capers, and cucumber but requested no sprouts) and a cheese bagel with jalapeño cream cheese. I loved my lox, perfect amount of everything and super filling! As for the other bagel, they definitely skimp a little bit on the cream cheese if you're not ordering a sandwich. It sort of tasted like I was just eating bread with jalapeños. Other than that, there's a few tables outside which was great for us since we had our dogs, and plenty of things to do and see in the area.
author: Jamie B.

description:
came by for a quick breakfast after my workout at crunch.
The place was small and the bagel baskets were almost empty when I came in Friday around 10:15sh.

Parking is tough
Place is clean but not very pleasant.
I ordered herb bagel with cream cheese... eh, it's okay.

service was okay too.

I've had better bagels some place.
author: Learnee L.

description:
You rock, Bagelry. 

Thank you for being my breakfast-on-the-run spot. 

For $4 you'll give me a nice bagels with eggs, tomato and cucumbers. 

I love the variety of bagels you have. 

I also enjoy the outdoor seating. 

Thank you for being open early.
author: Carlos A.

description: It was my first time visiting this local bagel joint.  Friendly service and rather quick prompt on the delivery.  I got the everything bagel with jalapeño cream cease and a fried egg. The egg was over cooked though - I'll have to ask next time to ease up on the heat.  Oh, and I was hungover..but, I still like my bagels.
author: Vik M.

description: Over all for a egg, bacon, cheese, & bagel sandwich for the price of $5 it is excellent. The flavor is on par though the atmosphere is very limited. I definitely recommend this as a stop and go location. Though it does have a more local and non corporate feel to it as a plus. 4 stars would of been 5 if the location was cleaner and better setup for eating and sitting.
author: Matthew F.

description:
If you like bagels, this is the place to go. With a GIANT bagel to catch anyone's eye, I had to A). take a picture and B). stand in line. It's one of the best places for breakfast and has dozens of variety bagels. From what I remember, they were able to give me whatever I wanted without telling me, "Sorry, we don't have that." 

From my sister who is a food enthusiast in San Francisco, this bagel shop is the best one in the city and I am lucky to have been able to eat there. :D
author: Lily L.

description:
Final destination.

Unmemorable movies: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Final_Destination_(film_series)

Memorable views: http://www.yelp.com/biz/ina-coolbrith-park-san-francisco#hrid:8xpve32ZbNl3SXj522u1Zw

Lunch from the Bagelry joined us at our destination.

Roasted turkey, light cream cheese, sprouts and tomato on a whole wheat bagel was about $7. Like the movies, perhaps entertaining/good (never saw), but soon forgotten.

Same can't be said of the view. That won't be forgotten anytime soon.
author: Jason B.

description: Real bagels not the fake ones you get at Noah's. The bacon, egg, and cheese bagel is the way to go!
author: Allen C.

description: Wow!  They have the best bagels in SF!  Get there early as it is so yummy once freshly baked.  I can't believe a bagel is only a $1?!  Best breakfast, lunch or snack on a low budget.  If I live close by, I would go everyday.  They really take care of their customers that they even know how I like my blueberry bagel with lite strawberry cream cheese.  If I want savory, I get lox and bagel.  It's such great service that they automatically greet me and ask "sweet or savory?"  What more can I ask for.
author: Tammy T.

description:
I have been coming here for a long time now. My routine is usually popping in to place order, then head next door to Pete's to grab coffee, and by the time I come back the bagels are usually ready. I typically order 3 at a time. 
I recommend the Bacon egg and cheese bagel and my girlfriend loves the everything bagel toasted and tries different spreads (lately a fan of the dill).
Overall convenient, something for everyone, and great grab-and-go breakfast spot!
author: Tyson B.

description: Fresh bagels. Fun spread selection and good sandwiches. Family ran which makes me like the place even more. Fair prices. Parking sucks. Awsome coffee.
author: Terese V.

description: F-ing hate this place. Food is meh, staff is incompetent.
author: Nicole C.

description:
I will say upfront that I am not from New York and have only had a handful of bagels while visiting there. However, without fail the Bagelry delivers me a ham, egg, cheddar and tomato sandwich on an everything bagel perfectly each time. 

The stack of ham, tomato and fried egg seem perfectly designed to fit on the bagel. With each bite you get all that you asked for with little mess and absolutely no remorse since the sandwich is not too greasy. 

It is quite frankly the best breakfast bagel sandwich I have had and have continued to have for the past few months.
author: Mark A.

description: Always an obnoxious line on the weekend. You pay $1 extra for avocado and they give you a sliver. Staff are clearly stressed and not very enthusiastic about customer service. Today was my last visit. Going back to Noah's or Posh.
author: Heather L.

description: Check out their bagel sandwiches. For about $6 you get a loaded bagel/egg/whatever else you want sandwich and a bottle of water/soda. Super tasty too. Way better than Noah's. Hands down.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Lines long and out the door? Damn that sucks.
No place to sit? Crap, really?
No more bagels?! What your out???!


OK. If you find a place that enough people go to to wait in line for, fight for seats and bagels for is any place worth checking out.
The bagels are sooooo yummy. Alone or in a sandwich doesn't matter. 

You gotta try these bagels! Never goin back to Noahs or *cringe* Starbucks haha
author: Janai F.

description: Ahh, the Bagelry, what would I do without you? I go here at least twice a week --- I can't get enough of their BLT and egg with cream cheese on an "everything" bagel. Highly recommend. Friendly staff, great service & very convenient if you're in beautiful Russian Hill.
author: Lauren R.

description:
Sesame bagel, light creme cheese, and a slice of tomato. Nom nom. This is my goto treat when I visit the Bagelry. It has a convenient location on Polk St, located near Peets and Starbucks. The bagels take a while to be toasted so it's a safe move to put in an order and go over for a tea or coffee.

Con's include incorrect orders. It's happend multiple times -- I've ordered one thing and got something else. It's also a bit pricey if you want to get a drink to go with your bagel. All in all, it's a solid breakfast place and I would recommend it to people that wanted to stay on Polk.
author: Jason M.

description: My favorite breakfast bagel in the city. They are so delicious here and the service is great. I used to live a block away and, of everything, I miss this place the most.
author: Ryan S.

description: I have a love/hate relationship with this place. The bagels are the best I've found in the city so far. However the wait times and spreads are the worst. 99% of the time I'll just order a couple of untoasted bagels to go and grab cream cheese across the street at Real Foods or Walgreens...yes Walgreens brand cream cheese is better. On the rare occasion I'm grabbing something to eat on the go - like today - I'll order something toasted, with their spread and regret it. Every. Single. Time. I start to wonder what's wrong with me that I will actually keep trying their spread and rationalize it with 'maybe if I get a different flavor, it'll be decent'. Nope. And don't get me started on why we can't get a decent bagel in our fair city. How is it that my small hometown in AZ could produce a better bagel than one of the best food cities in the world? And no, I'm not going to wait in a 2 hour line for a pop-up bagel shop. Not going to happen. So until I learn to make my own bagels, I'll continue my weekend morning visit to this place.
author: Naomi W.

description:
I just ordered a sausage, cheddar, and egg bagel sandwich.  I was blown away by the fact that they used a REAL fried egg and REAL sliced sausage- unlike Noah's.  This place is great, and I plan on returning for all my bagel needs.

Remember to bring cash!
author: Joe L.

description: The East Coast pulls me back for the delicious bagels!  This bagel spot was pretty average but good for SF.  A blueberry toasted bagel with walnut and date spread was a great choice.
author: Vanessa L.

description:
The first time I came here, I wasn't much of a fan. The place was very busy, and that was probably part of the reason I didn't have a pleasant experience. They got my order wrong (toasted my bagel when I didn't want it toasted-- doesn't sound like a big deal, but I really didn't want mine toasted haha). They only had a couple of garlic bagels left (one of which I ordered), and proceeded to give it to the lady who ordered 2 dozen bagels behind me in line. I watched them put all the garlic bagels in her bag and made sure to immediately ask them to save me one since I ordered before her. Thankfully they took it out of her bag and prepared my order with the last one. Had I not been watching, they would have given it away and it would have really pissed me off. 

I came again this morning on my way to Starbucks because I really wanted a bagel with cream cheese, and Starbucks doesn't come close to making decent bagels. It wasn't crowded, and they had plenty of bagel flavors left. This made me quite happy. I ordered, and paid my $2.50. They got my order right this time which was awesome! I highly enjoyed my bagel, and will definitely be back to try their other bagel and cream cheese flavors. Maybe the trick is to come when it's not super busy.
author: Ashley D.

description: This place is a-ok just as three stars signifies on yelp. The help wasn't outgoing - just there to take your order. I found my bagel pretty doughey and lacking in flavor. Another patron actually asked me, "if the bagels were fresh today." Yikes...anyway, I thought the cream cheese was delicious. I ordered the chive and cucumber cream cheese and the other person I was with seemed to enjoy her everything bagel. Oh well. Maybe I am snobby when it comes to bagels being from the Northeast close to NYC...
author: Karin R.

description:
Consistently mediocre. By far the cheapest breakfast option on this stretch of Polk...but at what cost? At...what...cost?

They do have bagels, and eggs, and bacon...but they WILL forget your cream cheese/tomato/whatever extra you added so double check your order.

OK on the weekend when every other breakfast joint in Russian Hill is slammed but on the weekday spend a few extra dollars and get something that's actually tasty, not just life sustaining, from the other options on the block.
author: Corbin C.

description:
This review is based on approximately 10 visits over the last 1.5 years.

The good: closest place to my house (otherwise one star only)
The bad:
Service is so incredibly bad and slow.  Seriously 20-30 minutes for a toasted bagel with a (very thin) coating of cream cheese.  Eggs? Bacon? add at least 10 minutes, yup 40 minutes of standing there like an idiot waiting for a $3 bagel.

Product: Just really, really bad bagels.  Generally they taste like day old bagels from Safeway.  They have clearly determined that margin is to be made on cream cheese, i.e. don't give the customer more than just a quick swipe of the valuable stuff!
If you dare venture into the world of eggs, bacon, cheese etc.  get your bowel ready for some grease, and lots of it.  As somebody that has easily eaten a thousand bacon, egg, and cheese bagels I would give these a 0 out of 10.

So in closing, if you have nothing to do with your morning, and I mean nothing, head on over here for a bagel.  It will take the better part of your morning to get out of there.  Couple this with your strong desire for an extremely unsatisfying bagel experience and you have found your utopia!  Enjoy!
author: pat y.

description:
TERRIBLE customer service. Really, you're not closing for another 45 minutes and you refuse to make more coffee? And are rude about our letting you know that you're out of the coffee we paid for? 

(if I have one pet peeve, it's when someone other than the person actually helping you loudly complains about whatever you're ordering that they don't feel like serving you.) 

This is a bagel shop. People like coffee with bagels. The markup on a cup of coffee is what, like 2000%? and you won't make more? Geez. 

Our bagels themselves were pretty good. Nice toast on them and the spreads were decent. But given the coffee situation and how grungy the ceiling, counters and floor are, we won't ever come back.
author: Emily C.

description: I'm a Jew from the east coast -- I value my bagels.  The bagelry is delicious and cheap... my only complaint is that they sometimes sell out of inventory before 1pm.  I come here often.
author: Jonathan S.

description: I didnt know that a spread of creme cheese meant the thinnest possible layer of cream cheese possible. This place needs to take some hints from Dan Farr, and when I say I want cream laid thick then layer that schemer in clumps so it fills each crevice in my mouth.
author: B S.

description: Would definitely give more stars if they didn't skimp on the cream cheese.  Highly recommend getting a bagel and a small cup of cream cheese. If you're splitting it between two people, it's both cheaper and gives you enough for each.
author: John B.

description:
I've experienced better. But a nice bagel does beat waiting in line for 'not very fresh' bagels and pastries from neighboring pete's coffee and Starbucks. 

I ordered a sesame bagel with egg ( they use fried eggs only) turkey and chive cream cheese. It was about $6 or $7. 

I must say I do love creative cream cheese selections and this place had it all! The turkey was a bit dry and the sandwich wasn't as good as I had hoped. I'm used to good ol' blahs bagel. They always get it right. 

I wouldn't be opposed to trying this place again. 
 
My recommendation: Bagel and cream cheese only please...
author: Heather H.

description:
Ah... the memories. The boyfriend and I used to come here years ago every morning for bagels and starbucks (next door) before school. 

It used to be a smaller operation. It's grown quite a bit. It seems like these days, the staff has grown (I think it's mostly his family members). The owner was always super nice to us. He'd give us a free ham and cheese crossant here and there. I actually ran into him a couple of times after not having been in a few years. He recognized us! 

It's a great place with all kinds of bagels and all kinds of choices to put into your bagels. However, they aren't open very late and I'm not sure they're open every day either.
author: Jeanette P.

description:
They've burned my bagel every time I've been there, and last time I went they only had blueberry bagels.  What kind of bagel place runs out of bagels?
Also, as mentioned in my previous review, it's not as nice on the inside as it is on the outside.  Like a nasty factory with cramped standing room only.
author: Light Bulb J.

description:
Solid bagel place. Fresh. I'm a
minimalist, so I go for toasted onion
light on the cream cheese. Right near Peets coffee. 
Get your bagel, get your Peets, relax on Polk in the morning. That's SF!
author: Rob B.

description:
BEST BAGEL IN SF!!!

As a native New Yorker (yes, The City), I get righteous about my bagels.  This place satisfies ALL my concerns.

Get the salt bagel with lox, cream cheese, tomato, onion, and capers.  Thank me later.

Street parking in this area is a biatch.  Try stealing parking from Walgreens, or park a block away at the Pacific or Jackson St. meters.

CASH ONLY.
author: Dmytro A.

description:
I had hoped the Bagelry would deliver a crispy on the outside, chewy on the inside bagel. What I got was definitely decent, bordering on good, but it was not what I had hoped for.

Will not go out of my way to come here.
author: Miriam W.

description: The bagels aren't good at all and the service is so slow. The bagels at Starbucks or Philz are much better. Will not be back.
author: Jillian P.

description:
"Bagel Me, Bagelry."
(it's funnier in a Sean Connery accent...)

I like that even after a few initial visits, the friendly lady who works the register on a typical weekday knew exactly what I wanted before I'd ordered it. Like Cheers, but with bagels (boy, bagels and beer.. that's  a concept... but I digress). 

The Fried Egg and Bacon sandwich is a special treat - They don't nuke the eggs like at other places; you can watch them fry it up right in front of you. 

I'd change it so they cooked the bagels in a wood-fired oven for the smokey flavor, but that's just cuz I'm so critical.
author: Razoo D.

description: A slightly above average but far from amazing bagel place, I have been a patron of this Bagelry for many years.  They have a few tasty bagels which I regularly enjoy- such as their garlic, onion, and cheesy bagels, and also they have a few spreads I regularly choose- their sun dried tomato and their herb & garlic.  I go savory with my bagels as you can probably guess.  There is no other bagel competition in the area, and I call their bagels basically a tie with your average neighborhood Noah's location.  I prefer House of Bagels on Geary over these guys but alas this is a 2 minute walk from my home...For my favorite bagel in California- try the Pesto and Pizza bagels at Rude Brothers in South Lake Tahoe....it's a bit of a drive from SF however :-)
author: Andy S.

description: I've gone here twice for breakfast  bagels and the service is great. I'm always welcomed with friendly smile too! The bagels are fresh and I love that you can eat outside and people watch.
author: Chanel B.

description:
I like The Bagelry. Homeless people like The Bagelry too. It seems like someone is always out front asking for a bagel and one guy went so far as to try to custom order a bagel from this woman on her way in. What's the world coming to? :)

On the weekends they always have lines - be prepared to wait if its Sat. or Sun. morning, but not for too long. They keep the line moving. I have never had the coffee, but the bagels I have gotten are fresh and well toasted. The prices for the take home cream cheese containers are really cheap and a plain bagel starts at $1. 

My personal fave: The egg bagel toasted with cream cheese, tomatoes and red onions is a dream breakfast.
author: Natalie N.

description:
I had to run out the door for a quick last minute appointment this morning, so had to miss breakfast (which is a ritual I practice daily - gotta start your day off right!)

So after the appointment and running errands all around town (I literally walked from the TenderNob to the Loin, then all the way to Russian Hill), I was famished and my blood sugar low. 

Enter The Bagelry. Large selection, fast service and best of all: they slice it evenly & spread the cream cheese perfectly! None of that oozing out the sides when you eat it as a sandwich.
author: Sally M.

description:
Onion bagel, fried egg, cheese, and cream cheese (just for good measure). BAM, hangover cure. 

The bagel was a little on the small side-hence why I docked a star.
author: Melinda S.

description:
When there's no House of Bagels (the best!) nearby, The Bagelry comes in an essential Second Place.

Bagels are sizable, flavorful, and straddle the line well between bready and doughy.  The only persistent irritant is their inefficient order system.  And by that, I mean their system for both taking and delivering orders.

C'mon guys --- parallelize a little.  Could it hurt to add another cashier / bagel-picker?
author: Droo G.

description:
It's really loud in here. Try to avoid if you have plans to hear in your later years. 
Bagels are OK, but not worth losing your hearing.
author: Dan W.

description: Go in the morning (they close relatively early anyway). They have delicious breakfast sandwiches with freshly cooked bacon and sausages.
author: Zack B.

description:
Great food, but expect a wait!

I have waited for more than 20 minutes. Pretty insufficient operation but the best bagels around.
author: Tyler L.

description: Ah the Bagelry.  I see you just about every Saturday and Sunday morning, and you never disappoint. Except when I can't get myself out of bed until about 1:30 and arrive to find that you have run out! Being from the East Coast, and having tried many delicious New York bagel places, I really think this is the best bagel place in SF that I have tried so far. I generally stick to the Really Seedy bagel (i.e. Everything bagel) with cream cheese, but have tried the sesame & the egg bagels as well. Their sandwiches are really good too-- generous size, tons of toppings and cheap prices! Yes, it's cash only, but they state that really clearly on the register, and I am used to a lot of bagel places with this rule, so it doesn't bother me at all. Definitely recommend The Bagelry if you're looking for a fast, cheap and delicious breakfast.
author: Katelyn B.

description:
There have been days when the only time I emerge from my apartment is for a Bagelry run. There are also times when I bring $5 with me to the gym specifically for a kick-ass post-kickboxing meal on my way back. 

My personal fave: provolone sandwich on a really seedy bagel.  It comes loaded with sprouts, cucumbers, lettuce, onions and tomatoes that are so perfectly distributed across the sandwich that you wonder whether the super sweet people of the Bagelry are actually robots.  (Sadly, they often run low on sprouts/lettuce on weekends..)

They can get busy so I usually call my order in.  Service is unfailingly friendly.
author: Joyce W.

description: Bagels are good, but they need fresher ingredients (tomato, avocado) they do their best to keep up with the line, but I think they need an extra hand!
author: Leia V.

description:
Bagelry - I have to like you since you are the closest thing I will get out here to an H&H bagel.  Your bagels and your chive cream cheese in particular get 4 stars. 

You get 1 star for the efficiency.  I thought I beat the weekend hangover rush - which in theory I did - but when only ONE PERSON out of FOUR who are standing there are prepping the bagels - I mean, CMON.  4 out of 5 times I just want to get back there myself and help the girl out who is doing 75% of the work.  

Dude who is taking the orders and putting the bagels in the toaster - how about grabbing a knife and putting some cream cheese on the bagels that are sitting in a pile and getting cold???

yet I keep going back bc there is no where else to go and I actually do think your bagels are tasty.  
I highly recommend getting the bagel as is, buying the tub of cream cheese and doing it yourself at home.
author: Jessica W.

description:
OMG, the Lox Bagel on that last rainy Saturday morning turned into the worst FOOD POISONING of the century! and not only that, it was my B-day celeb on Sunday which I missed, vomitting in the emergency room, and had to listen to people sing me a B-day song over the phone while having my cake!! this is my first review ever and I made a point of it since a decision to keep the fish for a few more days probebly to save a few bucks really ruined my week, my B-day and my internal organs! I am still to this day paying for it! On the first bite,  the Lox smelled a bit too fishy & was a bit slimy and i took some of it out but apparantly not enough to 
save my poor stomach!! NEVER AGAIN, will I eat here, or even a lox 
bagel for a long long time......
author: Rami K.

description:
My favorite saturday mornings include keeping my sweatpants on grabbing the dog and walking down to the Bagelry with my man!  I love that place!  
One time they got the order completley wrong!  I brought the bagels home and I had to walk the 6 blocks back and pick up the correct order.  
No Bueno Begelry!  No Bueno!
Since then I have discovered that you can CALL AHEAD!!  Makes waiting in line a breeze and it is always ready!
author: Holly S.

description:
Note to the reader: the only true type of bagels are Montreal style bagels.  Which means they are crispy on the outside and soft, sweet, and gooey on the inside.  Look it up on Wikipedia.  It also says that Montreal style bagels are the only real type of bagel and not any of this mass produced bullshit or New York style trash that other people on Yelp seem to think is good.

That being said the Bagelry has NO Montreal style bagels.  What it does have are freshly made bagels with decent spreads.  Its efficient, quick, and reliable.  In the end its no St. Urbain Bagel but is a decent shop nonetheless.
author: Peter C.

description:
The place itself is a little dingy and scary looking, but the bagels and cream cheeses are delicious, and the service is fast and friendly-enough... I will be back.

**Cash Only**
author: D S.

description:
For a bagel shop, their bagels aren't very good. 

In the past two years that I've had a Yelp! account, I only used it for reference on good places to go. I didn't yelp before stepping into the Bagelry but I'm yelping to all those bagel lovers out there: DON'T GO TO THE BAGELRY!

I was one of two customers in the shop (the other was already waiting to be robbed). As I approached the counter, the cashier finally noticed I was ready to order so he hurried to finish whatever he was doing and said to me, "what would you like to order?" No smile, never mind the hello. 

My favorite flavor when it comes to bagels is blueberry. I was excited to find that they had both blueberry bagels and blueberry flavored cream-cheese and that's exactly what I ordered; one blueberry bagel with blueberry cream cheese.

The total was $3.00 flat. I could've gotten the same order at Noah's for $2.15!

Thinking that I would have time while they were fixing my order, I left to get a drink at the Starbucks down the street. 6 minutes had passed before I had gotten my drink and was back at the crime scene. I entered the place hoping to find my breakfast waiting for me on the counter but there was nothing. 3 more minutes had passed until one of the workers said "Blueberry on Blueberry". 

Jumping out of my seat, I went over to claim my prize. I took the bagel and headed over to work. When I sat down at my desk, my mouth was so watery, I didn't even wash my hands before I started to unwrap the yellow paper that stood in the way of me and my bagel. The bagel looked good, it even smelled good but when I brought it to my mouth and took my first bite, there was no sinking of the teeth. There was no crunch of the toasted bagel. There was no oozing of the cream cheese. There was NO SATISFACTION. Instead, there was this pasty excuse of a spread which tasted like medicine on something that was tough and cold. I don't know what it was but it was definitely not a bagel.

Never going there again, 

Mon.  

I'm all for supporting the small local businesses but the truth is that NOAH's is a much better choice than the Bagelry.
author: Monica R.

description:
Coming from the east coast (NY/NJ) giving up bagels was on my initial "con" list for making the move.  Until I met the Bagelry.

Most places in SF bake their bagels, but somehow I ended up only a few short blocks from one of the few places that knows how to do it right and boil their bagels. I don't know why people bother with baking - I mean go eat a roll or something. But a "Really Seedy" (aka everything) bagel with cream cheese from the Bagelry hits the spot every time. I try to limit myself to 2 a week (Friday morning and one weekend morning), but have yet to be consistently successful with plan.

One thing I have noticed is that because of the decrease competition for bagels (and pizza) the are definitely more expensive here than on the east coast. But I will happily fork over a few extra bucks for a good bagel that reminds me of home.
author: Katie W.

description: You have no idea how amazing this place is.  I moved to the neighborhood 7 years ago and worked on the block.  I became ridiculously addicted to their toasted garlic bagels with light veggie cream cheese and all the veggies.  It got to the point where I didn't even have to open my mouth to order anymore - they would just make it for me :)  Then I moved away for a few years but recently moved back to the hood.  And I am completely addicted again.  Really really sweet people work there, the owner is great and I scarf down the bagel in 2 seconds because it's so damn good.  Even my mother in Arizona is addicted to this place.  Don't listen to the haters!  It's a small shop that only accepts cash and gets slammed on the weekends (because it's so good!) so sometimes you have to wait a bit for the bagel.  Big deal.  A small price to pay for a bagel orgasm in your mouth.
author: Erin D.

description:
The Bagelry is good, although I'm confused by those who've had NY bagels and say Bagelry is the same. There's no way these pint-sized bagels are comparable to the luscious, doughy pleasures served on the island of Manhattan. H & H ships and their frozen bagels are even better than anything on the West Coast.

Nevertheless, a good bagel is hard to find in SF. Unlike everyone else, I think Noah's is pretty good... I grew up on them, so maybe that's why. But I do recognize that Bagelry tastes different. My minor complaints are that Bagelry toasts the bagels too long- they're always borderline burned. Also, the bagels are too expensive. 

The wonderful part: The egg bagel sandwiches actually include a fried egg rather than a microwaved egg! I don't know many places that do this. It's terrific.

CASH ONLY, grrrr.
author: Amanda C.

description: Great for grabbing breakfast bagels on the weekend. Reasonably prices and great quality. Staff is very hardworking to get everyone in and out!
author: Laura D.

description: Always a good bagel or bagel sandwich if you don't mind standing in line. The only problem I have with the place is that the food prep workers aren't wearing hairnets or hats. Yes, their hair is pulled back but there are lots of strays in their faces. Come on guys, nobody wants to find hair in their bagel sandwich.
author: B K.

description: best bagels in SF. better than any of the chain shops. ive walked by early in the morning in the wee hours and seen them hard at work baking bagels getting ready for the morning and open. Love the variety, all of the cream cheese spreads as well and i like ordering them in bulk or just popping in having one toasted with a cream cheese spread and tomato.. try garlic, everything, or sundried tomato bagel with jalapeno spread , sundried tomato spread, or even the chives spread... or you could have something sweet instead of savoury... they are all good. they do breakfasts as well, i wouldnt order coffee from here.
author: Julian I.

description:
Ladies and Gentlemen: let us take a moment to show some pity for the customers and fans of Noah's "Bagels," for, through no fault of their own, they cannot tell a real bagel from a piece of Wonder Bread.

For those not in the know, a bagel is a bread product made of dough formed in the shape of a ring, which is boiled and then baked. Bagels = boiled.  Not boiled = not a bagel. It's that simple. This is important to note for the simple reason that Noah's "Bagels" are not boiled, they are steamed. The end result is that you have a piece of Wonder Bread in the shape of a donut, just not as tasty. They do this, in order to maximize the amount of product they can produce. It's this process that has earned them the nick-name "McBagels." 

Fortunately, The Bagelry does not do that. They realize that to cook a bagel with steam is like cooking a medallion of tenderloin beef with an arc welder. Instead they kick it old-school, by boiling them before oven baking. The process may be a little slower, but the result is a genuine bagel with a hard exterior, and a chewy interior. 

The Bagelry does pride itself on offering one of the best New York-style bagels (meaning salt is used in the dough-making process, not sweeteners such as honey. That would be a Montreal-style bagel), along with other offerings that one would expect to find in any of the Five Burroughs: YooHoo, celery and egg cream sodas, high-quality salmon, the Sunday Times, everything but your typical New York attitude.

Like a good West-Coast bagel shop, expect to find the usual wide variety of bagels and flavored cream cheeses as well as the expected garden toppings. Other nosh-able items are available, such as ham and cheese breakfast bagels, and bageldogs (highly recommended) are also at the ready for your "nom nom nom" enjoyment. 

But, as good as this place is, there are some down-sides: supplies quite often run out quickly, it's usually a bit dirty, and lines out the door are common in the mornings. But considering the product, and that all leftover bagels are donated to various food charities, these are minor problems. 

So in conclusion, if you're looking for a bag of breakfast treats for your office, or are just in search of your Sunday morning coffee and a salt-bagel with lox and schmeer, you'd be hard-pressed to find a better bagel shop in the area, or in the city for that matter. Highly recommended.
author: Randy M.

description: I used to always come here for their bagels. Local favorite.
author: J C.

description:
Tuna bagel + a bag of chips or a soda = $6.00.

The tuna had way too much pepper and it was just all over the bagel including the bottom, sides and the top-  very messy to eat.

Service was good but I'll probably get a different kind of bagel other than the tuna next time.
author: M W.

description: The bagels are so good and are filled with just the right amount of cream cheese.  The shop is a little small so don't go expecting to eat in the shop.  If you find a place to sit, consider yourself lucky.  They didn't have any Chocolate milk so that was a minus.  They also took an awful long time to toast and add the cream cheese to our bagels...I don't know why.  The place is pretty popular with new customers coming in every 5 minutes.  The shop was really close to our hotel so we just walked there one morning for breakfast.
author: Carlos U.

description: The bagelry  is the only place I can take New Yorkers. Bagels are fresh and not too doughy.  I really like their poppy seed, onion, sesame, and garlic bagels. If you want to pick up a few dozen, give them a call the day before to ensure you get your favorites - they'll have it ready for you the next morning.
author: Win S.

description:
Yesterday on my walk to work I was thinking that I should ask the owner of The Bagelry to open up a 2nd location in the FiDi.  
More like, BEG him actually.

After all, I do need to turn left to get to work and The Bagelry is to the right.
I'm sick of Noah's and they're not nearly as good. I don't want to pay $3.75 at La Boulange for a veggie croissant anymore either.  

Being from the East Coast, this is the closest I have come to repeating my H&H addiction.  

The weekend ritual is to order my usual (Really Seedy bagel w/ sun dried tomato cream cheese, tomato & cucumber) then run over to Peets to order my latte, timing it so I can make it back to Bagelry just in time to pick up my bagel sandwich pipin' hot.  Timing here is critical, people.  Critical!  

(Warning: Do not be that indecisive person in front of me at Peets. It could get ugly.)

Next on my "Beg-the-owner-of -The Bagelry" to-do list --- DELIVERY!!

Again, timing here is critical, people. I will have to take it slow with my requests.  But you'll thank me if you're ever hung over, feeling like death in the middle of drunk-sleep, wishing SOMEONE, ANYONE would just deliver you some breakfast!  

Hmmm, maybe you should ask him too!  Deal?!
author: Lauren C.
