description: i used to walk by here and get bagels on my walk to school. when i was younger and remember it being one of the best bagels in the city. they would give you great portions on the toppings especially the cream cheese. i went here the other day and ordered my usual and barely anyone was inside. my order took very long but that was ok since i remember their bagels tasting great and that it would be worth my wait. instead this time this wasnt the case. i ordered and bagel with herb garlic cream cheese with tomatoes and onions and the entire thing was so damn skimp. the topping were sliced so thin that what i was used to. the worst part was the cream cheese was spread on as thin as possible to where you could barely even notice there was any cream cheese on the bagel. i left very disappointed because i was craving a bagel with cream cheese instead i got basically bread with thin sliced veggies. i guess its back to noahs bagel now since their service is more consistant
author: Art N.

description: I remember this place because of the giant bagel in the front of the store so the bf and I got breakfast here since we figured it would be cheap. We got 2 onion bagels to go with cream cheese and that was $5. That's pretty expensive compared to Noah, but this place does give you A LOT of creme cheese which is kind of gross because it is like everyone said at least a pound heavy.  This place is own by Asians and they were very friendly. I might come back here I mean it was convenient location to walk too. :]
author: Alice H.

description:
I love the begals here.  Too bad begals aren't great for you.  MMM, especially the cream cheese!!!!

I typically get the Onion Begal with Garlic Cream Cheese.  You know my coworkers love talkin to me after I down one of those!

MMMMMMM.... come here...
author: Noneya B.

description:
The Bagelry.  The name implies that they sell bagels...and they do, as long as you get there before they run out.  Show up around noon and you're stuck with blueberry or plain.  Here's an idea...if you're constantly running out of 'everything' bagels, maybe you should make more!  
The bagels themselves aren't bad.
author: phil h.

description:
A good friend of mine has an ongoing rivalry with Mr. Bagel at The Bagelry. Personal skirmishes aside, I think they make a damn fine bagel.  

Since my college days, an 'everything bagel' with tomato and cream cheese is the only breakfast food that will really rid me of the hair of the dog. Keep 'em coming!  I haven't gotten sick of them yet.
author: Nicole G.

description: Good bagels. Great breakfast bagel sandwich, they fry an egg to order.  Best bagels I've had in sf.
author: Katie M.

description:
Ok, if you're not of the tribe, you can't really judge the fact that this and Katz bagels are the ONLY places in S.F. that should be allowed to call themselves bagelries.

   Noah's should take note, a real bagel is not simply bread that's round. It's a boiled, gently conceived nugget from the heavens that should be smeared with cream cheese and topped periodically with some nice lox. Oy vey.  

The Bagelry keeps it simple. No tofu-infused bagels with a pinch of paprika. Sesame, plain, or onion is how it should be.  Maseltov. And have fun storming the castle!
author: Ben S.

description:
Ambiance it has not.  But the bagels are pretty damn good - tasty without toasting, which, as any bagel freak knows, is the hallmark of a truly good bagel.  Plus, they have a giant bagel floating outside, so you know they're for reals.

I have an insatiable hunger for bagels, which runs against my unfortunate current attempt to be semi low carb.  Trying to at least be semi-good this morning after a night of excess, I ordered one of their low carb bagels, thinking that at least the tasty olive schmear would cover up it's undoubtedly cardboard-like properties.  But lo and behold, if my everything low carb bagel didn't taste pretty damn good.  It's a small glimmer of hope for me in this crazy, crazy world.

Update: I had to change my rating to five stars.  I eat here almost every  day, for pete's sake.  Oh, and confidential to the person who occasionally comes and buys all the low carb bagels before 9:30 AM.  I will find you and do ugly things to you.  That *&^% is not cool.  Leave one poppy or face the consequences.
author: Tanya N.

description:
As a former New Yorker, this is a very sensitive subject for me.  I really dislike the bagels in San Francisco.  I don't think House of Bagels is very good at all.  This is the best of what's around in my opinion, and they're pretty good.  They now offer egg on a bagel and they way they do it with cheese and salt and pepper is quite tasty.  

I hate their lox spread, but their cream cheese is really good. I don't bother getting the actual lox here though. I get it from a guy at the farmer's market.

And I wish it would stay open later. It would be good for dinner from time to time.
author: Ashley S.

description:
So if you live in San Francisco long enough, you forget what a delicious, piping hot, doughy bagel is supposed to taste like.  You try noah's, but the soft flat bagel is not really your cup of tea.  You try getting "fresh" bagels at whole foods or safeway, but even your toaster oven and some delicious cream cheese + jelly can't salvage what you just purchased.  

At this point, you are beaten down by the bagels in san francisco.  (side note: I don't know much about the bagel-making process - seems like some boiling is involved? - but seriously, how hard could this be??)  You are considering asking your mother to ship you some across country.  You are wondering if an English muffin could ever replace a tasty salt bagel.

And then, you are walking down Polk street on a saturday morning, and you see a massive crowd standing underneath a larger than life bagel... you must be in heaven!!  These must be tasty and delicious!!  Well, you'll find out that it's maybe not heaven but it's as close to it that you will find in the northern streets of SF!

Get there early b/c your favorite varieties (aka salt and wheat raisin) will be gone when you arrive.  It doesn't matter what time, you should have come earlier b/c they will be gone. 

Despite all of the above, I'm a fan.  Even if they are not the best bagels in the word, they are the best ones around.
author: Lisa R.

description: OMG, this is the BEST bagelry in SF. Hands-down. I have been going here at least 3x's a week to get bagels from Bob (the owner). The wheat sesame and wheat raisin bagels with light cream cheese and cucumbers. mmmmm.
author: Karen S.

description: Favorite breakfast place in the city so far.  There is always a line and you can rarely find a place to sit, but they have decently priced bagel sandwiches that are really good!  My only problem is that they do not take credit cards.
author: Robb M.

description: My favorite Bagel place in SF...been going here since 1993. Growing up we would go to House of Bagels on Geary. I do love that place but The Bagelry is better. The whole wheat sesame is my favorite...can't go wrong with any of them. Good customer service too. Although I miss the lady who used to work the counter, not sure where she went. About 3 months ago they said she was on vacation, STILL?
author: Susie T.

description:
Stacy H may be Jewish, but I am both Jewish and from New York City, and grew up at Katz's and Henry's delicatessens on the lower east side.  I think Stacy H must have been having a bad day.  I just came back from one of my regular trips to NY a few weeks ago with a bag of H&H bagels - widely regarded as the NY Standard for bagel perfection.  After my wife and I ran out of those, I happened by The Bagelry whilst in Russian Hill and thought I'd give them a try.

I have to say that if these weren't identical in form and quality to H&H, they were damned close.  These are not light bready bagels like those at Noah's and Posh - these are chewy boiled rings of New York goodness here on the left coast.  Stacy - chill out.  Do an A/B with a Noah's and you'll see that your 1-star rating is way out of whack.  You don't have to love the shop or the staff or their decor or their prices, but these bagels are the real thing.  Check 'em out.
author: Josh M.

description: Given the fact that they're the only bagel place around, I guess they can do what they want. Since I live so close, I come here about once every three weeks for a lazy bagel fix. It's amazing because just about every time they seem to mess something up on my order. Am I the only one in the bagel-eating world who doesn't like their bagel toasted? More often than not, I am given a toasted bagel, regardless of how many times I repeat "not toasted". What irks me more is when I pay for tomato on my bagel only to get home to realize they forgot it (but still charged me for it).  It's also a bummer to be the unlucky one who ends up getting a burnt bagel. At more than $2 a pop, give me a bagel that's not completely scorched on the bottom. Quality control people, quality control! Come on!
author: Kalie M.

description:
When I want a bagel I go here.  

The line sucks.  They need more indoor seating.  Their coffee sucks.  

Their bagels ROCK.

Their cream cheese ROCKS.

I LOVE THE BAGELRY.
author: Sarah T.

description:
Who on earth orders plain bagels these days??? Personally I'm all about flavors, so I opt for the Everything practically every time. 

I was moderately impressed with the "Seedy" bagel at the Bagelry - and let's face it, just walking in off the street and ordering something seedy is fun in itself. If you don't love an abundance of garlic and onion flecks, you may find this bagel overpowering. Definitely plan on carrying breath mints to suck down on the way to your post-bagel client meeting.
author: Leela S.

description:
Poor selection of bagels unless you're there when they open.
$6.50 for an egg/ham/cheese bagel.
Inferior to Lenders, Noah's, Starbucks and Costco bagels. 
Cash only.
Service without a smile. 
Relatively dirty interior and exterior.  

Something ain't right.
author: Brian H.

description:
closest ive found to a decent ny bagel..  fresh bagels, dont know why they ask u if u wanna toast it each time but cause theyre usually warm..  killer bacon egg n cheese on an everything.

-1 star for calling everything bagels 'very seedy'
author: Brian K.

description:
I really wish I could love this place but I don't. I go here against my will because there isn't another place nearby that I can grab a quick bagel egg sandwich. There are two main problems here IMHO:

1) I feel like I'm interrupting their day. There's no personality whatsoever. It's strictly business. If I want that kind of treatment I'll go get an egg mcmuffin.

2) $3 for a lousy slice of turkey or ham on the mediocre at best, egg and cheese bagel. $3.75 for an egg and cheese bagel. $6.75 for them to add a slice of meat on that sandwich. I think a homeless person could do a brisk business by going across the street to The Real Food Co., buy some of their lunchmeat (assuming they even have any, that store is worse than Whole Foods in terms of not being able to get "normal" grocery items), sit outside of The Bagelry and sell each slice for $1 or $1.50. Considering that they don't melt the cheese anyway it really wouldn't matter that it was cold. Heck that homeless person could setup shop with a toaster oven and finish the job that The Bagelry can't seem to do. 

Please, someone open up another place where you can grab a quick, reasonably healthy breakfast as there's nothing on this part of Polk St and make these guys shape up.

They get 2 stars because the bagels themselves are actually really good.
author: Michael K.

description:
It's a bagel. 

As already stated by several others, Ben S. in particular, very few of the other so called "bagel shops" sell bagels. Round bread with a hole does not a bagel make. 

Their lox could be better (sliced more thinly), but all in all, it's the best I've found west of the mississippi.

I'm headed there right now.
author: J Z.

description:
These bagels tasted terrific!  Well maybe it was all of the pesto/tomato sauce I got on mine.  The bagel was quick, warm and the service was prompt and not snotty.  What else can you ask for from a bagel shop?  
Well they also had some hugeonomous mural painting on the wall with all sorts of SF stuff on it.  

4 stars for all the selection they have.
author: patrick o.

description:
I'm from New York and this place is the truth...I can't say that I've tried their bagel sandwiches but for a simple bagel and cream cheese (i prefer veggie, but they have all kinds) there's no place better.

lines can be a bit long on the weekends but they're usually pretty quick with service. also, get there early cause sometimes they run out of your favorite kind...

also, every saturday, there's been this awesome enormous dog waiting in line. usually he's really tired so he kind of just lays in the doorway. extra star for that dog.
author: ramya r.

description: Thank you for (mostly) curing the nastiest hangover I've had since my college days....and for having egg bagels.
author: Joanna S.

description: I love bagels so I decided to try this place after being disappointed by House of Bagels . I've actually been here once before but don't remember how the bagels taste like so I decided to come here again a few weeks ago . I had the sesame bagel with onion & chives cream cheese which was alright . I didn't really like the onion & chives cream cheese though because I found it tasting kind of weird and too salty . I also had a bagel sandwich which wasn't that great . Their bagels are pretty good ... better than the store-bought bagels out there because these bagels are less bready than store-bought ones . The bagels here are more light and chewy . They're pretty cheap too for fresh bagels ... only $1 each . I'll probably come here some day for breakfast if I ever wake up super early ... seems like a good place to go in the morning .
author: Eileen L.

description:
Sorry Whit, I have been cheating on our South Beach Diet!

Nothing can keep me away from my bagel shop! The pound of cream cheese is a meal in itself. I can begin my own cream cheese shop with the amount I scrap off. But I still love this place. Try fresh tomatoes on your next fresh bagel.
author: Dee C.

description:
The bagels here are good but the sandwiches, however, not so much. Last time I get a sandwich here, it was coated with grease and its contents dull. A slice of kraft singles atop a slice of luncheon ham and a whole lot of butter laid lifelessly in my bagel, and it tasted of it too. 

They're ok if you're looking for bagels and spreads, but Star Bagel, a few blocks over, has much better sandwiches. But I do love that they have outside seating and they are right next to Peet's!
author: Deanna T.

description: This place has served me well on many a hungover Saturday mornings. The lines can get a little long on the weekend, and they only take cash, but it's worth the effort.
author: Allison B.

description:
My favorite quick grab-a-bagel on the weekend spot.  They make their bagels fresh every morning.  Once they run out, they are closed - which can be anywhere from 1pm - 3pm. 

While I really try to avoid too much bread because it just makes me feel lethargic, it's hard to resist a toasted really seedy bagel with butter and cheddar.  They have every bagel imaginable.  

The downside (which can turn this quick spot into the long drawn out ordeal) is the buggy pushing mommies and daddies who want to squeeze into the tiny little space with their strollers and wait till they get to the counter to decide what they want after they debate loudly which would be the better choice.  Then they stand right in the way waiting, mommy, daddy and stroller, until they get their bagel and once they get it then they have to disrupt the entire line trying to squeeze back out the door.  But of course, they must first stop right in the doorway before finally exiting.  How many times have they run through this drill?  Don't they get it yet?  

The girls at the counter can sometimes overcharge because the computer register can be a little tricky.  If in doubt, ask and they will get Kahn (the owner) to come over and he will get it straightened out.
author: Kathleen K.

description:
Ok, I'm not an MOT (member of the tribe) but I believe my Jewish stepfather and my general love of all things carbohydrate give me some street cred in reviewing bagel shops.
This place is awesome--great, great bagels.  To be sure, I've only gone on weekends and, now that I think about it, probably before 11am so I've yet to experience the depleted selection that other yelpers have had to contend with.  My Super Seedy (I think that's the name--The Bagelry's take on an Everything bagel) with cream cheese, tomato and onion has done me right on many on occasion.  The bagels themselves are mercifully chewy, dense, and fresh.  Now you're not going to become life long friends with the (sometimes surly) girl at the cash register but, let's face it, that's probably not why you're in there.  Stare at the psychadelic bagel mural on the wall while you wait for your carb fix and then get out.
author: Auburn D.

description: I walk in, I order, I walk out. Simple, fast & cheap. The gals are always friendly and smiling. The bagels are always sliced evenly. Believe it or not, this is hard to come by!
author: Thomas Nathan S.

description:
When they have them, their salt bagels are delicious. The problem is they make one batch and never make more. I used to think I just came too late, but I have been going earlier and earlier and they are always out - I have now been denied 8 times in a row. I used to think this place was a five star bagel joint, but waiting in line for a place that doesn't take credit cards, and is out of my favorite choice, and then doesn't have the "everything" bagel as a back up? I am done being disappointed. So now I need to find a place that has salt bagels that isn't Noah's. 
Take a clue guys, if you run out of something regularly and have too much of another thing regularly, you do one thing well and another not so good. Don't make people buy something they don't want, make more of what they do. Oh, and take credit cards, I don't need you to take Amex, just some plastic would be nice, people would buy more there. But never mind that if you can't just make enough of the things you run out of.
author: Sean Q.

description: I ordered  a whole wheat bagel with egg and bacon which costed $4.00.  The bagel was fine but was overpriced.  I went to The Bagelry because I read an article about where to find the best bagels in San Francisco.  I don't think I'll take that writer's advice ever again.
author: Lisa L.

description:
I don't like bagels.  They are doughy, mealy, boring and have a ton of calories to boot without a lot of taste.  This place is usually out of bagels on the weekends...the odd time that we have walked by with a bagel hankering, they were out of bagels at 11:30 am...whatever. 
I once had a lox sandwich from here and it was ok, about 6 bucks, not too bad for the amount of smoked salmon you get.  
Their coffee really sucks but its ok since Peet's (yay!) is right next door.
The place is bare and has no ambiance, the service is ok, not too friendly but efficient.  I rarely come here...only when someone I am with is really into getting a bagel because again, I don't like bagels.
author: Nilu r.

description:
I'm a big fan of this place.  Well, I am a big fan of bagels in general and I would eat one every day if I could.  For $2.50 you can get your favorite bagel with whatever topping and ya know, that ain't bad for breakfast.  The lo-carb (really seedy) tastes great too but a little on the salty side.  I'm pretty sure they are one of the best bagel spots in the city.

As for the three stars - their hours are messed up.  The run out of bagels at weird times and I constantly have to call to make sure they are still open.  Hopefully, things will change and they will start making more bagels at least until a decent hour because as somebody that works late and gets up late, its needed.

CASH ONLY!!
author: Gemma S.

description:
Great bagels, but I wished they made egg sando's.  That would make this place a five star.

UPDATE:  This place is under new ownership now, and they do make egg sandos, but they aren't fresh (they keep the fried eggs in a chafing dish).  So, they still don't earn that coveted 5th star)
author: Andrew C.

description:
They run out of most bagels and their coffee disappears by 11:30 am (what do they do until 3?).  Don't come here looking for lunch unless you like, uh, plain or sesame.  Which you probably don't, because it's obvious everyone loves onion and garlic just as much as I do.

I once got a bagel with garlic spread and it was less like cream cheese with some garlic in it and more like garlic paste with a smidge of cream cheese.   My breath could have melted a bouquet of roses; just a little too much!
author: Argonaut A.

description:
If you are not sure that you like bagels, you have to try the lox here! This is my new obsession and I don't know if it's good or bad for my figure, but my weekend trips to this place make me really happy :) It's kind of sad there is not much seating and the chairs are not particularly great. Also they run out of bagels really early.. at around 11:30 there are just 3-4 flavors to pick from. On the bright side, the condiments make all the difference and I am usually cool with whichever flavor I get 'stuck' with when I wake up late. And there is Pete's coffee right next door, to get a latte while I'm waiting for my lox bagel.

Bring cash!
author: Mira S.

description:
The bagels are darn good, especially early Sunday morning when you have to wait in line (I don't mind at all) with your Peet's coffee from next door.  If you prefer the puffy monstrosities of Noah's and the usual white rolls you get from any chain, you won't like the bagels here. 

Toasted and buttered, these are crispy and chewy...
author: Melissa G.

description:
The bagels here are really really good -- crispy on the outside, soft on the inside. I live near House of Bagels in the Richmond area and have lukewarm feelings towards that bagelry, sorry! 

The Bagelry in Russian Hill doesn't compare to any other bagel I've had. I get the onion or everything bagel with herbs & garlic spread (low fat, regular, and tomato pesto spreads are yummy too).
author: Jane C.

description: love this place, best bagels in town
author: Jimmy D.

description:
If you're accustomed to the variety, consistency and schnazzy layout of Noah's Bagels, The Bagelry probably won't knock your socks off.  It's grown on me over the years, though.  It's a nice neighborhood bagel place with all the essentials.  

I now find it quite comforting, standing in the line on a weekend morning in my pajamas and a coat, usually fighting a hang over. 

Suggestion:  If you are after coffee - get a large - their small is about the size of a Dixie cup.
author: Carolyn H.

description:
I'm giving these guys 4 stars because they actually have the best bagels in San Francisco. I'm a total bagel snob, having been raised on bagels in and around NYC. I would say the Bagelry's stuff is one notch below H&H in New York. 

If you are looking for an authentic bagel, look no further. They aren't the smooshy steamed type you get at Noahs, Costco, etc. I'm shocked to see another review here actually saying Noahs bagels are good. In my opinion, Noah's bagels are tasteless, squishy, and foam-like. 

Now, as for the establishment and service, it's not amazing, but what the heck, I'm just ordering a bagel and creme cheese, so I don't expect 5 star service. I realize people in SF are used to pristine looking establishments, but again, if you'd ever been to a real bagel shop where they make their bagels, you always find them a little run down (because they are cooking the bagels here). And again, I'm usually running inside to order a bagel, and then eating it outside or at home, so I don't really care what the inside decor is like.

Bottom line: if you want a terrific and authentic bagel, go to the bagelry. If you want a pristine establishment, fast-food like service and a crappy bagel, go to Noahs.
author: Chirpy M.

description:
Ridiculously good bagels & spreads for ridiculously obnoxious prices.
ONLY when you REALLY, you know, HAVE to have that breakfast.
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description: I wouldn't call myself a bagel connoisseur, so I'm not going to comment on the quality of those, but I know a worthwhile establishment when I see it regardless. I don't want to make this place out to be something that it's not, either. Don't expect to be wowed by the interior or get lost in its charm. A dingy ATM greets you on the outside, and there's not much for the eyes inside. Don't expect to sit and lounge with your meal. Bagelry is very casual, fairly quick and you get plenty of bang for your buck. You can get a filling and quality breakfast sandwich for five bucks, and with a varied selection of bagels, spreads and other toppers, you shouldn't have trouble finding something for you. I had heard before visiting that this place can get slow, but I am yet to experience a noticeable delay in my orders. I do wish they would put up a big menu inside to help order (I think the only current menu is a sheet sitting on the counter), but I can't find much to gripe about outside of that. I give it a thumbs up
author: Taylor C.

description: My daughter and I spent a week in San Francisco. Our hotel was within walking distance of the Bagelry, but I did not stumble upon it until the next-to-last day of our trip. Shame on me! Their bagels are fantastic (although I might feel differently if salt bagels were my favorite). I have also had bagels in NYC, and think that these stand up quite well to those.
author: Charles L.

description: I walked across town to check this place out, after getting the Scoutmob coupon (and I don't have the "App", so I had the printed off copy), and started to order, placed the Scoutmob on the counter, and the lady behind the counter apologized and explained that they didn't honor them anymore. But the expiration date says 5.21.12! Ok, whatever- but then don't make up some ridiculous explanation that your scanner is broken, because every other Scoutmob-affiliated business has simply taken the paper, or written down the number, and that was that. But her response was that it was too much work for them to gather the numbers and then call Scoutmob--- it's very simple, it's called an Excel file, just copy down the numbers and email it to them--- and then she tried to sell me on their App (again, no smartphone). We were hungry, so we tried to order food anyway, but then they don't take credit/debit, even for an order over $5. But you have a scanner for your smartphone app? I don't understand. I'm just really disappointed that businesses like this exist where they use services like Scoutmob as a huge advertising ploy, and then when customers venture into their store as a result, make up some story and don't honor the deal. Go to House Of Bagels, they are both friendly, honor coupons, and make killer bagels.
author: Amanda S.

description: Everything bagel with sundried tomatoe cream cheese and cucumbers, delicous!!1
author: Jenny I.

description: I'm sick of getting a single, unripened tomato slice on my bagels. why even offer the option on the menu? their bagels are good but they're not that good.
author: Jason A.

description:
I love carbohydrates.  Nothing packs them in like a bagel.  I leave it to others to determine what is a "real" bagel.  Although, I have to agree with the "its not just bread with hole" crowd.  After that, the debate is probably about as useful as the "real" pizza debate.  

These are the first bagels I have had in San Francisco that I really like.  I stop here on the weekend on my way home after running at Golden Gate Park.  This is the quintessential bagel shop -- austere, hot, bagels in wire baskets.  I take them home.  So, I am not looking for a place to sit or prepared food or anything other than good bagels.  I just want to grab a dozen and go.   There is usually a line when I am there.  Like most real bagel shops, they will run out of a particular variety.  I'm usually flexible.  So, that is not a problem.  It is never the same ones.  So, I figure it is caused by the vagaries of day-to-day demand.  

Plain, poppy seed, sesame seed.  Even cinnamon-raisin, rye, pumpernickel and whole wheat.  But is blueberry a real bagel?  I never heard of such a thing before moving to California.  Oops, sorry, I was going to stay out of that debate.
author: Roy C.

description: I had the best bagel experience of my life here. My favorite bagel of all time used to be the asiago cheese bagel from Panera... but I have found something that tops it! The cheddar cheese bagel with egg, bacon and yes... MORE CHEESE was fantastic. It was huge, but I ate the whole thing. Love love love.
author: Tatiana J.

description: Probably the best bagels I've had in the Bay Area. They're always chewy and substantial with good, deep flavor. You could just smell it while they're toasting it up for you. With a big slab of cucumber dill cream cheese on it, and you're set. I like their fast and friendly service they provide and open early enough for me to grab a bagel on the go.
author: Juliane N.

description: Doesn't accept cards.  Not clean.  Always communication problems at checkout.  Overpriced.  Total letdown.  Needs new owners, Polk Street deserves better.
author: Anon A.

description: this place is great for an early morning breakfast, i love their really seedy bagel with fried egg cheese and sausage here, they use real fried egg and sausage not those freaking microwaveable egg and the really seedy they ran out really fast. I dont like to wait in line so most of the time i pick up the phone and call to order by the time im done waiting in line to pay for my order my sandwich is ready, or i just came early in the morning. Talk about the staff they are super nice, sometimes i want my bagel super crunchy and asked them to toast it a bit more dark, and they do it perfectly even though they are busy. i recently try their Jalapeno creamcheese, and oh boy oh boy oh boyy my second favorite i love it, the hotness of jalapeno and a kick of the herb it just perfect. They recently accept credit card now which even better.
author: charlie j.

description: So it's not an east coast NYC bagel, but it's pretty darn close. This particular visit to a west coast bagel maker was sheerly to absorb some of the not so great decisions of the night prior. I needed carbs and I needed carbs fast, enter Bagelry. The friend with whom I was staying said that she swore by these bagels...this friend is also from Philadelphia, so really, what does she know about good bagels? Apparently more than I thought because they were crisp on the outside yet wonderfully soft on the inside. I was advised to order a sandwich, I guess that's what the natives do. Back home, I order a bagel with butter...cream cheese at best; but after being advised to order all of their available vegetables with cream cheese so that I could boost my vitamin intake, it seemed as though I were the one being taught the art of ordering the bagel. If I find myself back in the area, I will go out of my way to get back here again, you should probably do the same.
author: Rebecca S.

description: Decent bagels. I'm a New Yorker, there's no way I can give a bagel place outside of NYC 5 stars! But the veggie cream cheese was quite good!
author: Irene F.

description: One of my favorite bagel places in the city.  Not because it's down the hill from me but because they are a good, nice, local business.  I like supporting those.  They are also not like Noah's where it's dough city inside....they are firm so eating one doesn't put you over the edge.  I like they cream cheese options and they make pretty good sandwiches too.  I haven't tried their fried egg bagel sandwich but I will sometime soon.  Especially since your other option for a breakfast sandwich is a nook ed fake egg thing at Starbucks.  Yech!
author: Kirsten M.

description:
*latenight review only* 

so while its not the best hotdog . . . they serve hotdogs with liquid cheese latenight.  i do believe they also have chili to adorn them as well.  so this is the perfect food to accompany some latenight food debauchery down the street at escape from new york . . . and then a short stroll here to finish it off.

can't really speak to the quality of the bagels though.  but if i was in need of a bagel during the day, i'll be sure to stop by . . .
author: Jason J.

description: Pretty good bagels, especially with lox, cream cheese, tomatoes, onions and capers. Its unfortunate, however, that they had run out of everything and onion bagels by 11am...
author: Nicolas H.

description: These bagels are okay.  I only go here because it's conveniently located by my gym and house.  Otherwise, I'd take House of Bagels anyday over the bagelry for sure.
author: Danielle V.

description: It's a good bagel.   Wish they had whitefish, but I don't hold it against them.
author: L W.

description:
The bagels are good, the service is not.

Also they put hardly any cream cheese on the bagels.  I went back to tell the person working there about it, and she didn't care and was really rude, then charged me $3.50 for extra cream cheese!  I hate this place.
author: Audra W.

description:
Oh the days when my unemployed counterparts and I sat outside the Bagelry with our donuts discussing our unemployment.

These bagels are truly delicious--- try the veggie spread, it makes chain bagel veggie spreads taste like sludge!:)
author: Erin C.

description: Being the nice jewish girl I am, I was practically raised on bagels. It was probably one my first ten words. So I know my bagels. Unfortunately this place doesn't have bagels. They sell bread that may look like bagels. But don't be fooled. This saddens me and is a great disgrace to the greatness of the bagel.  I respect the mom and pop shops in a world dominated by Noah's chains, but in the end, many of us here in russian hill just wish Noah's would move in. And they always sell out of bagels on the weekends, leaving nothing but blueberry left. It's just a shame to walk all the way over to be turned away bageless. And they close at 3pm (which pisses off, scotty, my roommate, since that is when he gets his lazy ass out of bed).
author: Stacy H.

description: After six months in NYC, I have decided that New York bagels have NOTHING on San Francisco bagels.  Not only that but I dare you to find a blueberry bagel in New York.
author: Amme P.

description: Because a bagel with cream cheese is practically my favorite meal, I am forced to go here because it's close to my house.  The bagels themselves are good, but I notice the advertised breakfast sandwich bagel is now $7.50.  Un. Real. You can get a full breakfast at most diners for that price.  Now they are offering hot dogs on weekend nights and yogurt, too.  I think they are schmearing themselves a little thin.
author: T-Bone L.

description: Decent bagels.  They now make egg and cheese bagels, which I believe has something to do with my asking for one on every visit for the first year I lived in the neighborhood :P  The major down side is that they run out of everything relatively early.  I know, it's my fault for not crawling out of bed before 11 on a Sunday, but it's still sad.
author: Amanda B.

description: Ok - I'm waging in on this Yelp-war - - these are the real thing!  ...I don't get it, some of the reviews here say they are the real thing, some demand they are not.  I guess that's why this Yelp dialogue is so great - it's a tribute to our lovely social inability to agree on something so simple as a boiled ring of dough (ha, a bagel isn't that simple though is it?).   Anyways, of all bagels, these are one of the best.  I've even tried making my own (boilded and all), and these are just as good, a lot prettier, and way easier to simply buy.  Plus, the soft pretzels they make here are killer.  ...Always good to grab-and-go or sit and eat at one of the few tables as you people watch and compare the caffeine crowds at Peets v. Starbucks v. Teavana v. Royal Grounds.
author: Today Y.

description:
I love this place! The bagels are the best in the city, as far as I'm concerned. The bagels are boiled, not steamed! And thus they taste like real NY bagels. It's one of the only places in the city that boils their bagels. And their egg/cheese sandwiches are perfect. They actually cook their eggs rather than microwave or steam them, and so they taste good. But my favorite is the sesame bagel with the most delicious veggie cream cheese in the city! 

And I think the owner is great. He's always made a point of remembering me and my family. We've been coming here for years, and will continue to do so.
author: Kristin H.

description: I think I ate at the bagelry every day of the work week for a year straight.  This is a wonderful, reliable shop. Long, the owner is a wonderful guy and a friend. And the bagel sandwiches are always served with fresh ingredients.
author: scott u.

description: SO excited to have a neighborhood bagel place!  the bagelry made my morning the other day, with a nicely toasted sesame seed bagel with cream cheese.  i will definitely be back.  i didnt try the coffee which is the other thing i would expect to be good at a bagel place - hopefully next time!
author: Carolyn B.

description: Truly perfect bagel with lox. 'Nuff said.
author: Sarah R.

description: A toasted hummus bagel should be middle of the fairway material for a bagel shop of any decency but these guys weren't even on the course.  barely edible hummus.  unlike the burnt bagel, the service was cold.
author: James B.

description: Good bagel sandwhiches...the bagels alone are nothing to write home about ,but their lox and cream cheese and the fried egg sandwhiches are actually quite good! I walked in around 11:15 and more than half the bagels were already gone!! Good for what it is...a mediocre bagel shop with decent prices and fast service.
author: Kristy M.

description: This is THE place to get a flat bagel.....if you don't know what it is or have never experienced one.....go here.  But go early, they sell out quick!  Sprinkeled with sesame, poppy or everything.
author: ERICA E.

description: I grew up in the "dirty jerz" and sampled many Jersey and NYC bagels, this is not a perfect bagel, but anyone who would rather go to Noah's is looney.  As stated by others, they actually boil, which is the right thing to do.  The crew is nice and they have salami and sprouts to put on a bagel sandwich in the afternoon!
author: Max C.

description: I think the bagels here are OK, decent if you are craving a bagel, but this won't be the best bagel you have ever had.  Bonus is Peet's, Starbuck's and Teavana are all close by so you can get coffee or tea to go with your bagel.
author: Katie P.

description:
if i could make this star brown i would.   
5 reasons this place is the biggest waste of polk street property EVER!  
1. its never open. the hours of operation are as hit and miss as the ingredients on the menu. 
2. the last time my sister went there "the guy that does egg bagels" had gone home early. ?whatever that means.  
3." light "cream cheese means a bit more than 3 inches worth. 
4. the prices are retared 
5.one time i was accused of "stealing" because i took a drink from my nantucket nectar (which rule) while waiting in line.  
if i could tear the huge bagel sign down i would, then i would roll it into the bay.
author: David R.

description: Closest thing to a New York bagel.  Wide variety of bagels and schmears.  They've got outdoor seating too!!
author: Keith S.

description: i show up at this place on 2-3 days out of the 5 i'm in the hood. AND while they may run out by 1pm (wednesdays, forget about it) it is still a scrumptious bagel, dude. where else on polk are you gonna get that? not at the coffe shops, not up @ california street. these are nice and chewy, boiled bread type bagels. its a good, walk in, walk out and eat at the park kinda joint. not a bring your homework or cellphone convo kind of place. i really just love their bagels and cream cheese...
author: Angie M.

description: Best saturday morning spot on Polk if you want a good breakfast for under $10.   They make awesome bagel sandwiches.  One of the few places where the ham is actually better than the turkey.  Really Seedy bagel is really tasty and everyone knows that because they run out early. Fresh n tasty!
author: Carley B.

description: Honestly, i've had better. Live in NY, worked at my own bagel store, had eaten Noah's, and this is really nothing special. I would think that the name implies something close to those delicious NY Bagels but they really don't. Guess i'll get mine from Noah's.
author: benjamin c.

description: This is such a neighborhood establishment but it is going down hill fast.  The bagels are still good, because the new owners bought the recipe from the original owners.  But service?  BAAAAAD.  First the new owner was late opening every week, so rather than have one of his employees open the shop, he just changed the hours to open later.  Now, he has been coming in late again.  What's next?  Opening at noon and closing at one?  Worse still, once he does finally open, he is grumpy and complains about getting up so early.  I don't think he got the concept of bagels being a morning food when he bought the business.  It is a shame that our beloved bagel shop is being run down like this.
author: cj f.

description: not bad if you like east coast bagels.... light on the cream cheese and your set to go...i could go for one right now.
author: rasaka s.

description: Suffers from the same problem bagel shops do all over, the overpricing of cream cheese. Good thing I am not a fan of cream cheese. I usually get a blueberry bagel, microwaved with honey butter. The honey butter is good but more oily than buttery and slightly too strong honey. I keep getting it though. Once, when I was feeling rich, i tried the date and walnut cream cheese and it was superb. Apparently it's made right there at The Bagelry in the morning. I give it props even though I hardly eat it. But honestly, you can buy a carton of Philadelphia for cheaper than there. I digress, the reason i keep coming back is because, after going there maybe 6 times, the woman not only remembered my order but while she was helping an incredibly obnoxious couple who could not make up their minds, she saw me annoyed and signaled to me that my usual was on its way. You can't beat being a local amongst tourists :X
author: Sarah I.
